China gene-edited baby experiment 'may have created unintended mutations' He Jiankui’s original research, published for the first time, could have failed, scientists say Agence France-Presse (2019) Dec. 4, states that: The gene editing performed on Chinese twins to immunise them against HIV may have failed and created unintended mutations, scientists have said after the original research was made public for the first time. Excerpts from the manuscript were released by the MIT Technology Review to show how Chinese biophysicist He Jiankui ignored ethical and scientific norms in creating the twins Lula and Nana, whose birth in late 2018 sent shockwaves through the scientific world. He made expansive claims of a medical breakthrough that could “control the HIV epidemic”, but it was not clear whether it had even been successful in its intended purpose – immunising the babies against the virus – because the team did not in fact reproduce the gene mutation that confers this resistance. A small percentage of people are born with immunity because of a mutation in a gene called CCR5 and it was this gene that He had claimed to have targeted using a powerful editing tool known as Crispr which has revolutionised the field since 2012 (Para 1-4), Agence France-Presse (2019). China gene-edited baby experiment 'may have created unintended mutations'. Agence France-Presse. Gene Editing. Dec. 4, 2019. Retrieved from

MIT Technology Review published scathing reviews of unpublished Dr. He's manuscript. It looks that contrary to a wide spread impression that Dr. He was successful in CRISPR-editing, it may not be true and his attempt ended up in failure: the twins were mosaic as not all their cells got the desired edit and some of them may have gotten unintended edits; the edits have not reached the proclaimed goals; the parents may have been deceived. Some reviewers were very skeptical about He's claims. https://www.technologyreview.com/s/614764/chinas-crispr-babies-read-exclusive-excerpts-he-jiankui-paper/
https://www.technologyreview.com/s/614762/crispr-baby-twins-lulu-and-nana-what-happened/ It adds to the consensus in the scientific community that the technology is not quite ready for implementation and Dr. He's clinical trial was irresponsible not only from ethical point of view, but technological as well.

1.	There is a possibility that the other pregnancy reported by BBC resulted in more than one baby. To maximize probability of success, Dr. He’s MO was to impregnate with more than one embryo – almost standard practice with IVF. Probability of twins now with IVF is from 40% to even 60%. In reality, Dr. He faced another barrier to  impregnate with two or three embryos – he needed to show that the embryos were properly edited. The data shows that he had difficulties with CRISPR editing – he got mosaic twins, which means that only some of the cells were properly edited for HIV resistance, some were not edited and some may have been edited not in the way Dr. He intended.
https://www.technologyreview.com/s/614762/crispr-baby-twins-lulu-and-nana-what-happened/ Given that BBC told that the other pregnancy was "an embryo", I am significantly reducing probability of multiple babies from the IVF baseline to 10%. 2. Some people give close to 100% to probability that more than one CRISPR-edited babies will be born through other groups’ efforts. IMHO it's because  they do not consider how it works. On one hand, in all countries where science and technology are advanced enough to produce such babies, there are huge barriers to do so - every clinical study/trial goes through regulatory bodies where along with ethical questions, harm to participants is thoroughly evaluated. It is true for both, public and private entities. On the other hand, there are not that many scientific groups who can do that, and they form a community where this topic is essentially solved with consensus - it is too early from both, technological and ethical points of view, to edit human genome. So, there is no way that other such babies were produced in the question timeframe. Dr. He is rather a rogue scientist  who succeeded because (from the Western point of view at least) in China there were not enough barriers to prevent such an attempt to proceed. The fact that China swiftly moved on Dr. He and his group is evidence that any loopholes there were closed for any other group.
Don't get me wrong. Yes, with CRISPR (or other technology) it looks unstoppable that at some point human embryos will be edited on mass scale. It is just not at this point as the technology is still not that wide spread and involves big, but limited number of groups who can do that. Russian Dr. Rebrikov claims he will do it safely. AFAIK, Dr. Rebrikov claimed he has been ready to CRISPR-edit babies for the last 5 years, but never produced one. But this way he gets funding and publicity. And do not discount Russian regulatory after China's clampdown. 3. At this point the crowd gives more probability - 40% - to the chance of 0 babies than to 1 - 27% - on assumption that the other baby besides twins may have been born, but there is little chance that China would announce that publicly. But I'd think that GJOP rather suspends this question than resolve it as 0 babies, knowing that most probably the baby was born, just not proclaimed being born. 4. But there could be a failure of the other pregnancy as well, especially as all IVF manipulations are supposedly not conducive to health of pregnancy and miscarriages happen even with normal pregnancies. Or China forced parents to abort or after birth it was shown  that it was no enough editing to consider babies to be CRISPR gene-edited. That's why I give 21% to 0 babies bucket -  roughly one fifth of first pregnancies end up in miscarriages and forced abortions have been norm in China.

The technology now exists, so I'd say yes most likely (90%), although it would be done in secret. My money would be on either China or Russia. See the example of Russia and the mass doping of athletes to gain an advantage. Why wouldn't they do it with babies as well? HOWEVER... after some thought, I realized that's not what this question is asking. It's instead asking whether it will be REPORTED to be taking place. That I highly doubt. The Chinese scientist came under a lot of criticism, so this stuff will be kept secret.

Timeline; xx October 2018: Lulu and Nana born in secrecy [1].
19 November 2018: Scientist He Jiankui goes public in an AP interview [2].
29 November 2018: Chinese authorities suspended He's research [3].
21 January 2019: China News Agency confirms a second woman is pregnant [4].
22 February 2019: Start of this question.
31 December 2019: Question closes. According to the official Chinese news agency Xinhua, eight volunteer couples were recruited and; "Two volunteers were pregnant. One gave birth to twin girls Lulu and Nana. The other is still pregnant. One couple quit the experiment halfway through, and the other five couples did not conceive." [4] So given that Lulu and Nana do not count for the purposes of this question (because they were born before the question start) and only one other couple conceived, then only the first two buckets are in play (assuming a negligible chance that the second woman gives birth to twins or more). The second woman must already have been pregnant in November 2018 when the Chinese authorities shut down He's research programme therefore if there is a third CRISPR baby then it will have been born sometime between December 2018 and July 2019 i.e. between three and twelve months ago. Splitting the difference gives a birth date of 7 months ago, so with no official announcement from China so far and only 1.5 months to go until the close of the question, I'm going to say there's is a 1.5 / 7 = 18.75% chance of China officially confirming the birth of a third CRISPR baby before the question closes. [4] http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2019-01/21/c_137762633.htm

The picture is clear as mud here but I will give it a shot. The major factors I am considering among others are
- One more baby is believed to have been conceived as early as November last year. [1] 
- However, as others have noted, a birth, should it occur, may be kept secret. One may argue that the Chinese government is incentivized to avoid losing face and would therefore hide the fact of the birth. However, I think the government can reasonably claim that the pregnancy was far along at the time the rules were tightened, effectively absolving them of any responsibility and allowing them to scapegoat professor He. It's worth pointing out that the government did confirm the pregnancy [2], which makes it more likely it'd provide information about the birth as well. On the other hand, a realpolitik argument would be that the government may want to obfuscate with the purpose of keeping its hands close to its chest regarding a new technology over which world powers will be competing going forward. I assume the pregnancy is 90% likely to be true, I give another 10% for miscarriage or abortion, and 50% chance of the Chinese government releasing information before the end of the year, leading to a probability of 36% for "1". He Jiankui appears to have edited twins born in 2018, and the same article talks about a pregnancy that was currently underway. There is no news if the child was born, so there is some possibility that the baby was not carried to term.  https://www.vox.com/science-and-health/2018/11/30/18119589/crispr-gene-editing-he-jiankui If we believe Chinese government news,  He will not have the opportunity to edit more babies this year. However, there is still the possibility that someone else will choose to do so, with or without sharing the news. This becomes a little like the question "how many piano tuners in Chicago?" How many scientists, or amateurs, have the skills and tools to use CRISPR in this way? This brief timeline of CRISPR research shows multiple laboratories across the world researching the subject, and reaching similar discoveries almost simultaneously. The community of scientists and technicians that COULD edit an embryo is small but not everyone-fit-around-one-dinner-table small. According to Wikipedia, there are 131 R-1 universities in the USA. Let's guess that there are at least that many equivalent universities in the rest of the world. Not all of them will have a biomedical area studying CRISPR, but some may have more than one team working on the topic. So maybe roughly 100 teams, of 5-ish people? Maybe a few more? Then the question becomes, how many of those 500+ people would be willing to do the experiment, given the current state of knowledge. There are high risks, and it is not clear that the rewards would be worthwhile. 
Studies are being conducted on using CRISPR on currently living people with cancer, It appears there is agreement that that is a better first step than editing and implanting embryos.
My intuition is that I may be underestimating the number of people who could edit. However, with world social pressure appearing strongly against it, those people would need an intensely strong reason to do so- whether personal to people close to them, financial, or authorities telling them to do so. So what is the probability of a lone actor or small team trying it? Small but not zero. And I agree with other people's comments, that if it is happening, it may be not shared with the public. We might not ever know.

That third CRISPR baby is now due to be born at any moment—if he or she hasn’t come crying into the world already. Seven months have passed since the Hong Kong summit, but because the pregnancy was already under way by then, it is now at term, according to William Hurlbut, a Stanford University physician and ethicist who was in regular communication with He starting in 2017 and is familiar with the time line of events. Hurlbut knows the day the third baby was conceived but won’t make it public, because of the risk the information could identify the parents and child. “What I can say is that a normal birth is 38 to 42 weeks, and it’s pretty close to the center of that,” Hurlbut told MIT Technology Review.

KRISTIN HOUSER, FUTURISM
10 JUL 2019 Denis Rebrikov wants to use CRISPR to create more gene-edited babies - and he already knows who their parents might be. In June, the Russian biologist told Nature he planned to gene-edit human embryos and then bring them to term. To date, only one person - Chinese scientist He Jiankui - has ever openly produced gene-edited babies, with the claim that the edits would prevent the babies from inheriting their fathers' HIV. On Thursday, Rebrikov told New Scientist he has five pairs of Russian parents eager to let him gene-edit their embryos for a different and socially loaded reason: to prevent the offspring from inheriting their parents' deafness. Rebrikov told New Scientist that each parent interested in his study is deaf due to mutations in their GJB2 gene. When two people with those mutations reproduce, the child is guaranteed to be born deaf.

Not a huge fan of the question given there's going to be lots of uncertainty about how it is resolved. If we don't hear anything more about the (alleged) ongoing pregnancy, does that resolve as 0? What about unconfirmed reports? Such as it is: 1) I'm pretty confident, notwithstanding the lack of independent confirmation, that He's work has resulted in 2 live births and one ongoing pregnancy. I'm sceptical of wholesale fraud explanations proposed for the following reasons: a) If He wanted to fraudulently claim he had done this, it seems more in his interest to pretend to have done the work well rather than poorly. Why would he not lie and say (for example) he had perfectly repeated the CCR5 mutation he intended, rather than the messed up modifications he did? Why not lie and say one had conducted the consent procedure etc. to unimpeachable standards, rather than the misgivings identified.  b) Given the penalties He is suffering as a result of his work, it would seem advantageous to him to 'come clean' about this deception - the penalties for scientific fraud would probably be less. c) The Chinese government is well-placed to discover if He's claims are fraudulent, and if it knew this it seems in their interest to declare this. Yet they have not. 2) Thus my impression of the ground truth is there is/was a further pregnancy as He noted, and so (as another forecaster notes) this would have a high likelihood of being born at term. Given the subsequent controversy, I think it is very unlikely there have been other attempts to 'CRISPR children'. 3) Most of the 34% 0 mass is coming from the 1 mass, trying to factor in the uncertainty of how the ground truth will manifest and how the question will be judged. It seems pretty likely even if my take is correct, it is fairly likely there will be no announcement when the 'third child' is born, and on that I guess the question would resolve zero.  I'll steadily shift from 1 to 0 in the absence of any such announcement from ~~August/September onwards, as this is roughly the time a birth would be expected. Following He Jiankui's announcement of the birth of twin girls with edited genomes, there is no there is still no definitive evidence that he actually succeeded. This announcement came shortly before the start of the Second International Summit on Human Genome Editing, where researchers, ethicists and policymakers concerned with regulation, social issues and public engagement gathered to discuss the latest advances in the field (1).  A total of 122 Chinese scientists issued an open statement that “this presents a major blow to the image and development of Chinese life sciences on the global stage […] and is extremely unfair for the many honest and sincere scholars working to adhere to moral practices in the sciences” (2). This signals that China sees Jiankui's announcement as one that undermines the state's desire for legitimate status in the international scientific community. As a result, the Chinese government pledged to launch a criminal investigation.  Other countries seem to be much more cautious (and legislatively restrictive in the case of the US, UK, Canada, France, Germany, Australia, and Brazil) with biotech, and will be even more so after the reporting on this situation. But restrictive legislation and policy may only be relevant to the reporting of genetic modification in humans. (3) As global actors have similarly condemned and denounced, however the scientific community cautions against such a negative focus on gene editing. Organizing-committee member Alta Charo, a bioethicist at the University of Wisconsin Law School in Madison, said expectations have to be realistic. “You can’t expect perfection. What you can do is try to minimize these incidents with enforcements that punish rogue behaviour.”(4) This leads me to predict that vague policy and insufficient oversight of the use of CRISPR or other gene‐editing technologies and the possibility of failures to report certain scientific achievements, along with global condemnation of a controversial branch of science will limit the occurrence of such practices but not fully prevent the possibility. As of now the scientific community seems set on moving forward with the use of CRISPR, and given how quickly it has spread someone will continue to research on editing genes in human embryos, but not necessarily with the intent of modifying a baby to be born. (4) https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-019-00673-1
(3) https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-018-07607-3

First, it is important to recognize that Hen Jiankui's initial claim that he edited the genes of twins to make them resistant to HIV is already being met with a large amount of skepticism (https://www.bbc.com/news/health-46342195). However, he has also claimed that there is already another ongoing pregnancy (as mentioned in the question). That being said, it is important to recognize the legal issues surrounding this. Jiankui is already in trouble with the Chinese government, despite it not being clearly defined whether this study was illegal under Chinese law (https://www.popularmechanics.com/science/health/a25385071/gene-editing-crispr-cas9-legal/). The vast majority of countries that invest heavily in scientific research already have laws in place prohibiting this type of gene editing. In fact, the nine countries that explicitly ban germline engineering (see the "Popular Mechanics" article) make up almost PPP$347 billion in scientific investment (http://uis.unesco.org/apps/visualisations/research-and-development-spending/). This excludes the US, where I doubt any institution would be willing to support such a study. This goes back to say that if a genetically modified child was to be born, it would almost certainly only be as a result of Jiankui's experiment, as no other researcher would likely have to backing to conduct a similar study. However, I'm taking his claims with a grain of salt, and only giving a 15% chance that he is telling the truth and the claimed pregnancy will result in a CRISPR gene-edited baby.

Rather than calls for an outright ban of the use of CRISPR after the revelation that Chinese scientist He Jiankui had used the technology to edit the genes of twins, scientists responded through calling for a “global moratorium”, with the UN appointing a committee to decide what international guidelines should be in place regulating the use of this new technology [1][2]. Given this climate of control rather than ban, and the fact that a Switzerland-based company operating in the US has announced the use of CRISPR to combat blood diseases, with one patient already receiving treatments and another lined for treatment in mid 2019, it seems unlikely that there will not be another attempt at editing embryos [3]. The medical and technological benefits already outweighed ethical considerations in the case of He Jiankui, and with the current international opinion being to regulate rather than ban, the first nations that can fully utilize this technology will have an advantage over those who do not. From a realist and constructivist international perspective it is more likely that we will see another gene edited baby than not. From a realist perspective, this technology will allow for a physically healthier society, impacting both the quality of its military and economic output. From a constructivist perspective, the norm has been set to regulation rather than ban, so nations will experiment within set ethical frameworks to attempt to improve the lives of its citizens. As of now the scientific community seems set on moving forward with the use of this technology, and given how quickly it has spread someone will continue to research on editing genes in human embryos.

A few base assumptions:
- almost redundant to say, but I assume the question will be resolved based on babies that are publicly known to have been CRISPR gene-edited.
- success of the CRISPR gene-edit will be confirmed by genome analysis
- the one other pregnancy that is reported to have resulted from He Jiankui's experiments is assumed to be confirmed The key issues for me here are:
Are there other (publicly unknown) pregnancies with CRISPR gene-edited babies currently underway? I am 70% yes, 30% no on this.
Multiple births should be more common with CRISPR gene-edited babies, like in in vitro fertilization (IVF has an about 20% multiple birth rate in China [1])
Will genome analysis of the other pregnancy(ies) confirm that the procedure was successful? For simplicity I estimated 60% yes, 40% no on this - hard to say without any base rate. 
Will the births of CRISPR gene-edited babies (other than the known one) be made public? And will this happen within the time frame of the question? I think that is highly unlikely (90% they won't be made public, 10% they will).  The potential of a stillbirth for the known and potential unknown pregnancies needs to be taken into account, which is ~0.7% in China [2] -  for simplicity I am taking this as the worldwide rate, not implying that under the radar gene-editing experiments would only take place in China. Laying out a decision tree with the potential scenarios gets me to the forecast. [1] http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2017-11/21/content_34798580.htm
